title: 107_s1469
content: The Act titled "Early Childhood Lead Poisoning Prevention Act of 2001" mandates lead poisoning screening for the Head Start and Early Head Start programs. The Head Start Act is amended to include lead poisoning screening requirements for enrolled children, ensuring they receive appropriate blood lead screening tests upon enrollment in the program. Entities may perform blood lead screening tests on children enrolled in the program, with reimbursement available for those eligible for or receiving Medicaid. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will reimburse entities for the cost of blood lead screening tests for children enrolled in the program, using funds from title XIX of the Social Security Act. This includes the Federal medical assistance percentage and potential additional costs for screening through certified clinical laboratories. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will reimburse entities for blood lead screening tests for children enrolled in the program, using funds from title XIX of the Social Security Act. This includes purchasing approved testing instruments and supplies for sites providing services under the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will reimburse entities for blood lead screening tests for children under title XIX of the Social Security Act. Funds will cover the enhanced FMAP costs for testing and data reporting. Authorization for early head start programs is provided for necessary appropriations for infant and child screenings. The subsection allows for blood lead screening tests on infants and children not covered by certain health insurance plans. It exempts children whose parents object based on religious beliefs and applies to head start programs for children under 3 years old. The text chunk discusses lead poisoning screening for the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children. Section 17(d) of the Child Nutrition Act of 1966 is amended to include lead poisoning screening requirements for infants and children participating in the program. State agencies must ensure that eligible infants and children receive a blood lead screening test upon enrollment, and refer those who have not been tested for the screening. State agencies must perform blood lead screening tests on infants and children enrolled in the program to determine if they have been tested and refer those who have not. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will reimburse State agencies for blood lead screening tests for infants and children eligible for medical assistance under the Social Security Act. The Federal medical assistance percentage will cover the cost of blood lead screening tests for infants and children, including the costs of providing screening through certified clinical laboratories or purchasing testing supplies for service sites. Blood lead testing instruments and supplies approved by the FDA for use in compliance with section 353, including tests for children enrolled in or eligible for SCHIP under a State plan. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will reimburse the State agency for the enhanced FMAP costs of blood lead testing and data reporting under title XXI of the Social Security Act. Authorization of appropriations is also provided. Authorization of appropriations is provided for blood lead screening tests on infants or children not covered by certain health insurance plans. Parents can object to the test for eligible children participating in the program. Parents can object to blood lead screening tests for eligible children if the test conflicts with their religious beliefs. SEC. 4. EFFECTIVE DATE. The amendments made by this Act take effect 18 months after enactment, with waivers available for WIC and Early Head Start programs. The Act recommends a plan to increase blood lead screening tests for children in WIC and Early Head Start programs, with waiver procedures to be developed within 12 months. The Health and Human Services will establish criteria and procedures, including a timetable, for awarding waivers under the Act to increase blood lead screening tests for children in WIC and Early Head Start programs.
